text: These are the words which Moses spoke to all Israel on the other side of the Jordan, in the desert, in the Arabah beside Suph, between Paran and Tophel, Laban, Hazeroth and Dizahab.
speaker: Narrator

text: It takes eleven days to travel from Horeb by the way of Mount Seir to Kadesh-barnea.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the first day of the eleventh month in the fortieth year, Moses spoke to the children of Israel. He told them all the Lord said they must do.
speaker: Narrator

text: This was after he had won the war against Sihon the king of the Amorites, who lived in Heshbon, and Og the king of Bashan, who lived in Ashtaroth and Edrei.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the other side of the Jordan in the land of Moab, Moses talked to the people about this Law. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Lord our God spoke to us at Mount Sinai, saying, ‘You have stayed long enough at this mountain.
speaker: Narrator

text: Get ready to travel now. Go to the hill country of the Amorites, and to all their neighbors in the Arabah, in the hill country and in the valley, in the Negev and by the sea, the land of the Canaanites, and Lebanon, as far as the big river, the river Euphrates.
speaker: Narrator

text: See, I have set the land in front of you. Go in and take for your own the land which the Lord promised to give to your fathers, Abraham, Isaac and Jacob, and to their children after them.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “At that time I said to you, ‘I am not able to take care of you alone.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord your God has made you become many people. Now you are as many as the stars of heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: May the Lord, the God of your fathers, make you 1,000 times as many as you are. May He bring good to you just as He has promised you!
speaker: Narrator

text: How can I alone carry the weight of your troubles?
speaker: Narrator

text: Choose wise, understanding and able men from your family groups. And I will make them leaders over you.’
speaker: Narrator

text: You answered me and said, ‘The thing which you have spoken is good for us to do.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So I took the leaders of your family groups, wise and able men. I made them leaders over you, leaders of thousands, of hundreds, of fifties and of tens, and rulers of your family groups.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then I said to your judges at that time, ‘Listen to the problems between your brothers. And be right in what you decide between a man and his brother or the stranger who is with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not show favor as you judge. Listen to the small and the great alike. Do not be afraid of any man, because you are judging for God. Bring to me any problem that is too hard for you, and I will hear it.’
speaker: Narrator

text: I told you at that time all the things you should do.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then we left Mount Sinai. We went through the big desert you saw which fills people with fear, on the way to the hill country of the Amorites, just as the Lord our God had told us. And we came to Kadesh-barnea.
speaker: Narrator

text: I said to you, ‘You have come to the hill country of the Amorites, which the Lord our God will give us.
speaker: Narrator

text: See, the Lord your God has set the land in front of you. Go and take it for your own, as the Lord, the God of your fathers, has told you. Do not be afraid or troubled.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all of you came to me and said, ‘Let us send men before us, to spy out the land for us. They will return and tell us which way we should go and which cities we will come to.’
speaker: Narrator

text: What you said pleased me. I took twelve of your men, one man for each family group.
speaker: Narrator

text: They went up into the hill country, came to the valley of Eshcol, and saw what was there.
speaker: Narrator

text: They took some of the fruit of the land in their hands and brought it down to us. And they told us that it is a good land which the Lord our God is giving us.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Yet you would not go up. You went against what the Lord your God told you to do.
speaker: Narrator

text: You complained in your tents, saying, ‘Because the Lord hates us He has brought us out of the land of Egypt to give us to the Amorites to destroy us.
speaker: Narrator

text: Where would we be going? Our brothers have made our hearts weak with fear, saying, ‘The people are bigger and taller than we. The cities are large, with walls as high as the heavens. And we have even seen the sons of the Anakim there.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I said to you, ‘Do not be afraid of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord your God Who goes before you will Himself fight for you. He did this for you in Egypt in front of your eyes,
speaker: Narrator

text: and in the desert. There you saw how the Lord your God carried you, as a man carries his son, in all the way you have walked until you came to this place.’
speaker: Narrator

text: But even so, you did not trust the Lord your God,
speaker: Narrator

text: Who goes before you on your way. He finds a place for you to set up your tents. He uses fire to show you the way to go during the night. During the day He uses a cloud to lead you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Lord heard your words and was angry. He swore,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Not one of these men of these sinful people will see the good land I promised to give your fathers,
speaker: Narrator

text: except Caleb the son of Jephunneh. He will see it. I will give the land on which he has walked to him and his children because he has always followed the Lord.’
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord was angry with me because of you. He said, ‘Not even you will go in there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua the son of Nun, who stands in front of you, will go in there. Tell him to be strong, for he will bring Israel into their new land.
speaker: Narrator

text: And your little ones whom you said would be taken by strange hands, and your children who do not yet know the difference between good and bad, will go in there. I will give the land to them. It will be theirs.
speaker: Narrator

text: But as for you, turn around and go into the desert by way of the Red Sea.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then you said to me, ‘We have sinned against the Lord. We will go up and fight, just as the Lord our God told us.’ So every man of you put on his sword and thought it an easy thing to go up into the hill country.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to me, ‘Say to them, “Do not go up or fight. For I am not among you. You would be destroyed by those who hate you.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: So I spoke to you but you would not listen. You went against what the Lord told you. In your pride you went up into the hill country.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Amorites who lived in that hill country came out against you. They came at you like bees, and crushed you from Seir to Hormah.
speaker: Narrator

text: And you returned and cried before the Lord but the Lord did not listen to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: So you stayed in Kadesh. Many days you stayed there.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then we turned and went into the desert by the way of the Red Sea, as the Lord said to me. We went around Mount Seir for many days.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord said to me,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘You have traveled around this mountain long enough. Now turn north.
speaker: Narrator

text: Tell the people, “You will pass through the land of your brothers the sons of Esau who live in Seir. They will be afraid of you, so be very careful.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not make them angry. For I will not give you any of their land, not even enough for a foot to step on. I have given Mount Seir to Esau for his own.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will pay them with money for the food you eat. And you will pay them with money for the water you drink.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Lord your God has brought good to you in all you have done. He knows about your traveling through this big desert. The Lord your God has been with you these forty years. You have not been without a thing.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: “So we moved on from our brothers the sons of Esau who live in Seir, away from the Arabah road, away from Elath and Ezion-geber. We turned and went by the way of the desert of Moab.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to me, ‘Do not bring trouble to Moab or fight them in war. For I will not give you any of their land for your own. I have given Ar to the children of Lot for their own.’
speaker: Narrator

text: (The Emim had lived there before. These people were many and powerful, and as tall as the Anakim.
speaker: Narrator

text: They are known as Rephaim also, like the Anakim. But the Moabites call them Emim.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Horites once lived in Seir also. But the sons of Esau took their place. They destroyed them and took the land for themselves, as Israel did to the land which the Lord gave them for their own.)
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Now get up and go over the river Zered.’ So we went over the river Zered.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was thirty-eight years from the time we left Kadesh-barnea until we crossed over the river Zered. By that time all the men of war among us had died, as the Lord had said they would.
speaker: Narrator

text: The hand of the Lord was against them, to destroy them within their tents until they were all dead.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When all the men of war had died from among the people,
speaker: Narrator

text: the Lord said to me,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Today you will cross over Ar and into Moab.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when you come near the land of the sons of Ammon, do not bring them trouble or make them angry. For I will not give you any of the land of the sons of Ammon for your own. Because I have given it to the sons of Lot for their own.’
speaker: Narrator

text: (It is known as the land of the Rephaim also. For Rephaim once lived in it. But the Amorites call them Zamzummin,
speaker: Narrator

text: a people as great, as many and as tall as the Anakim. But the Lord destroyed them, and the sons of Ammon took their place and lived in their land.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was as He did for the sons of Esau, who live in Seir. He destroyed the Horites, and the sons of Esau took their place and live in their land even to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Caphtorim who came from Caphtor destroyed the Avvim who lived in towns as far as Gaza. Then they lived in their place.)
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Now rise up and go on your way. Pass through the valley of Arnon. See, I have given you Sihon the Amorite, king of Heshbon, and his land. Begin to take it for your own, and fight with him in battle.
speaker: Narrator

text: This day I will begin to put much fear of you upon the nations everywhere under the heavens. When they hear about you, they will shake with fear and be filled with trouble because of you.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “So I sent men carrying news from the desert of Kedemoth to Sihon king of Heshbon with words of peace. They said,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Let me pass through your land. I will travel only on the road. I will not turn to the right or to the left.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will sell me food for money so I may eat, and give me water for money so I may drink. Only let me pass through on foot
speaker: Narrator

text: as the sons of Esau did for us in Seir and the Moabites in Ar. Do this until I cross over the Jordan into the land the Lord our God is giving us.’
speaker: Narrator

text: But Sihon king of Heshbon was not willing to let us pass through his land. For the Lord your God made his spirit and heart hard, so He might give him into your hand, as he is today.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to me, ‘See, I have begun to give Sihon and his land to you. Begin to take it for your own, so you may live in it.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then Sihon and all his people came out to meet us in battle at Jahaz.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord our God gave him to us. We won the fight against him, his sons and all his people.
speaker: Narrator

text: So we took all his cities at that time, and destroyed every man, woman and child in them. We left no one alive.
speaker: Narrator

text: We took only the animals for our own, and the things that were left behind in the cities.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was no city too strong for us, from Aroer by the valley of Arnon, and from the city which is in the valley, as far as Gilead. The Lord our God gave all to us.
speaker: Narrator

text: Only you did not go near the land of the sons of Ammon, all along the river Jabbok and the cities of the hill country. You did not go where the Lord our God told us not to go.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then we turned and went up the road to Bashan. Og king of Bashan and all his people came out to meet us in battle.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord said to me, ‘Do not be afraid of him. For I have given him and all his people and his land to you. Do to him just as you did to Sihon king of the Amorites who lived at Heshbon.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord our God gave us Og king of Bashan and all his people also. We destroyed them until no one was left alive.
speaker: Narrator

text: And we took all his cities at that time. There was not a city which we did not take from them. We took sixty cities, the whole land of Argob, the nation of Og in Bashan.
speaker: Narrator

text: All these cities were built strong, with high walls, gates and iron. There were many towns without walls also.
speaker: Narrator

text: We destroyed them, as we had done to Sihon king of Heshbon. We destroyed every man, woman and child in every city.
speaker: Narrator

text: But we took for ourselves all the animals and what was left in the cities.
speaker: Narrator

text: So we took the land at that time from the two kings of the Amorites who were on the east side of the Jordan, from the valley of Arnon to Mount Hermon
speaker: Narrator

text: (Sidonians call Hermon Sirion, and the Amorites call it Senir).
speaker: Narrator

text: We took all the cities of the plain and all Gilead and all Bashan, as far as Salecah and Edrei, cities of the nation of Og in Bashan.
speaker: Narrator

text: (For only Og king of Bashan was left of the children of the Rephaim. His bed was made of iron. It is in Rabbah of the sons of Ammon. It was as long as five steps, and as wide as two long steps.)
speaker: Narrator

text: “So we took this land for ourselves at that time. I gave to the Reubenites and the Gadites the land from Aroer, which is by the valley of Arnon, and half the hill country of Gilead.
speaker: Narrator

text: I gave to the half-family of Manasseh the rest of Gilead and all Bashan, the nation of Og, all the land of Argob. It is called the land of Rephaim.
speaker: Narrator

text: Manasseh’s son Jair took all the land of Argob as far as the land of the Geshurites and the Maacathites. He called Bashan after his own name, Havvothjair. And that is its name to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: I gave Gilead to Machir.
speaker: Narrator

text: To the Reubenites and the Gadites I gave from Gilead to the valley of Arnon, from the center of the valley to the river Jabbok, beside the Ammonites.
speaker: Narrator

text: I gave them the Arabah also, with the Jordan as its west side, from Chinnereth as far as the sea of the Arabah, the Salt Sea, at the bottom of the hills of Pisgah on the east.
speaker: Narrator

text: “At that time I told you, ‘The Lord your God has given you this land for your own. All you men with strength of heart will cross over ready to fight before your brothers, the sons of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: But your wives, your little ones and your animals (I know you have many animals) will stay in your cities that I have given you.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will stay until the Lord gives rest to your brothers as He has to you, and until they own the land the Lord your God will give them on the other side of the Jordan. Then every one of you may return to what is his, which I have given you.’
speaker: Narrator

text: And then I told Joshua, ‘Your eyes have seen all the Lord your God has done to these two kings. The Lord will do the same to all the nations through which you pass.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not be afraid of them. For the Lord your God is the One fighting for you.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “After that I begged the Lord,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘O Lord God, You have begun to show Your servant Your great power and Your strong hand. For what god is there in heaven or on earth who can do such works and powerful acts as You do?
speaker: Narrator

text: I ask of You, let me cross over and see the good land on the other side of the Jordan, that good hill country and Lebanon.’
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord was angry with me because of you. He would not listen to me. The Lord told me, ‘Enough! Speak to Me no more about this.
speaker: Narrator

text: Go up to the top of Pisgah, and look to the west and north and south and east. See it with your eyes, for you will not cross over this Jordan.
speaker: Narrator

text: But tell Joshua what is to be done. Comfort him and give him strength. For he will cross in front of this people. And he will give them for their own the land that you will see.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So we stayed in the valley beside Beth-peor.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now, O Israel, listen to the Laws I am teaching you. Do them so that you may live and go in to take the land for your own that the Lord, the God of your fathers, is giving you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not add to the Word that I tell you, and do not take away from it. Keep the Laws of the Lord your God which I tell you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your eyes saw what the Lord did because of Baal-peor. The Lord your God destroyed from among you all the men who followed the Baal of Peor.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you who stayed faithful to the Lord your God are all alive today.
speaker: Narrator

text: See, I have taught you Laws just as the Lord my God told me. So you are to live by them in the land you are going to have for your own.
speaker: Narrator

text: Keep them and do them. For this will show how wise and understanding you are. The people who will hear all these Laws will say, ‘For sure this great nation is a wise and understanding people.’
speaker: Narrator

text: For what great nation is there that has a god so near as the Lord our God is to us every time we call to Him?
speaker: Narrator

text: What great nation is there that has laws as right as this whole Law which I am giving you today?
speaker: Narrator

text: “Only be careful. Keep watch over your life. Or you might forget the things you have seen. Do not let them leave your heart for the rest of your life. But teach them to your children and to your grandchildren.
speaker: Narrator

text: Remember the day you stood before the Lord your God at Mount Sinai. The Lord said to me, ‘Gather the people together before Me, so I may let them hear My words. Then they may learn to fear Me all the days they live on the earth, and they may teach their children.’
speaker: Narrator

text: You came near and stood at the bottom of the mountain. And the mountain burned with fire into the heavens, which were covered with darkness and black clouds.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord spoke to you from the center of the fire. You heard the sound of words, but saw no body. There was only a voice.
speaker: Narrator

text: He told you His agreement which He told you to keep, the Ten Laws. And He wrote them on two pieces of stone.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord told me at that time to teach you Laws. So you might obey them in the land that you are going to have for your own.
speaker: Narrator

text: “So watch yourselves and be careful. For you saw no body on the day the Lord spoke to you in the fire at Mount Sinai.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not become sinful and make a false god for yourselves that looks like a body or object, like a male or female,
speaker: Narrator

text: or like an animal on the earth, or a bird with wings that flies in the sky,
speaker: Narrator

text: or like anything that moves on the ground, or like any fish in the water below the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be careful not to lift up your eyes toward heaven and see the sun and moon and stars, all the things of heaven, and be pulled away and worship them and serve them. The Lord your God has given these things to all the nations under the whole heavens.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord has taken you and brought you out of the iron stove, out of Egypt, to be His own people, as you are this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Lord was angry with me because of you. He swore that I should not cross the Jordan, and that I should not go into the good land the Lord your God is giving you for your own.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I must die in this land. I will not cross the Jordan. But you will cross and take that good land for your own.
speaker: Narrator

text: So watch yourselves, so that you do not forget the agreement the Lord your God made with you, or make a false god for yourselves that looks like something which the Lord your God has told you not to do.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Lord your God is an all-burning fire, a jealous God.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When you become the father of children and grandchildren and have grown old in the land, if you become sinful and make a god that looks like anything, and anger the Lord your God by doing what is bad in His eyes,
speaker: Narrator

text: I call heaven and earth to speak against you this day. You will soon be destroyed from the land you are crossing the Jordan to have for your own. You will not live long on it, but will all be destroyed.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will spread you out among the nations. And there will not be many of you left among the nations where the Lord will drive you.
speaker: Narrator

text: There you will work for gods made by man’s hands out of wood and stone. They do not see or hear or eat or smell.
speaker: Narrator

text: But from there you will look for the Lord your God. And you will find Him if you look for Him with all your heart and soul.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you are in trouble and all these things have happened to you in later days, you will return to the Lord your God and listen to His voice.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Lord your God is a God of loving-pity. He will not leave you or destroy you or forget the agreement He promised to your fathers.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Ask about the past days, the days before your time, since the day that God made man on the earth. Ask from one end of the heavens to the other. Has anything been done like this great thing? Has anything been heard like it?
speaker: Narrator

text: Have any people ever heard the voice of God speaking from the center of the fire, as you have heard it, and still live?
speaker: Narrator

text: Or has a god tried to go to take for himself a nation from within another nation, by trials, special things to see, great works, war, a powerful hand, a long arm, and spreading much fear? The Lord your God did this for you in Egypt in front of your eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was shown to you so you might know that the Lord is God. There is no other except Him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He let you hear His voice from the heavens to teach you. On earth He let you see His great fire. And you heard His words from the center of the fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: He loved your fathers, so He chose their children after them. He Himself brought you from Egypt by His great power.
speaker: Narrator

text: He drove out from in front of you nations greater and more powerful than you. And He brought you in and gave you their land for your own, as it is today.
speaker: Narrator

text: So know this day, take it to your heart, that the Lord is God in the heavens above and on the earth below. There is no other.
speaker: Narrator

text: Keep His Laws which I am giving you today. Then it may go well with you and your children after you. And you may live long in the land the Lord your God is giving you for all time.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses set apart three cities east of the Jordan
speaker: Narrator

text: where a person may run to, if he killed his neighbor without meaning to and had not hated him in the past. He might save his life by running to one of these cities:
speaker: Narrator

text: Bezer in the desert on the plain for the Reubenites, and Ramoth in Gilead for the Gadites, and Golan in Bashan for the Manassites.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the Law which Moses gave to the children of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the Laws which Moses spoke to the children of Israel when they came out of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were on the other side of the Jordan, in the valley beside Beth-peor, in the land of Sihon, king of the Amorites who lived at Heshbon. Moses and the sons of Israel won the war against him when they came out of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: They took for their own his land and the land of Og king of Bashan, the two kings of the Amorites, east of the Jordan,
speaker: Narrator

text: from Aroer beside the valley of Arnon, as far as Mount Sion (that is, Hermon).
speaker: Narrator

text: They took all the Arabah east of the Jordan, as far as the sea of the Arabah at the bottom of the hills of Pisgah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses called all Israel, and said to them, “Listen, O Israel, to the Laws which I speak in your hearing today. Learn them and be careful to live by them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord our God made an agreement with us at Mount Sinai.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord did not make this agreement with our fathers, but with us, all those of us alive here today.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to you face to face at the mountain from the center of the fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: I was standing between the Lord and you then, to tell you the Word of the Lord. For you were afraid because of the fire and did not go up the mountain. He said:
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘I am the Lord your God, Who brought you out of the land of Egypt, out of the house where you were servants.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Have no other gods except Me.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Do not make a false god for yourselves, or anything that is like what is in heaven above or on the earth below or in the water under the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not bow down to them or serve them. I, the Lord your God, am a jealous God. I punish the children, the grandchildren and the great-grandchildren for the sins of their fathers who hate Me.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I show loving-kindness to thousands, to those who love Me and keep My Laws.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Do not use the name of the Lord your God in a bad way. For the Lord will punish the one who uses His name in a bad way.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Remember the Day of Rest, to keep it holy, as the Lord your God told you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Six days you will do all your work.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the seventh day is a Day of Rest to the Lord your God. You, your son, your daughter, your man servant, your woman servant, your bull, donkey or any of your cattle, or the traveler who stays with you, must not do any work on this day. So your man servant and woman servant may rest as well as you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Remember that you were servants in the land of Egypt. The Lord your God brought you out of there by a powerful hand and a long arm. So the Lord your God told you to keep the Day of Rest.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Honor your father and your mother, as the Lord your God has told you. So your life may be long and it may go well with you in the land the Lord your God gives you.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Do not kill another person.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Do not do sex sins.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Do not steal.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Do not tell a lie about your neighbor.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Do not have a desire for your neighbor’s wife. Do not desire your neighbor’s house, his field, his man servant, his bull, his donkey, or anything that belongs to your neighbor.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Lord spoke these words to you while you were all gathered at the mountain. He spoke with a loud voice from the center of the fire, the cloud and the darkness. He added no more. And He wrote them on two pieces of stone and gave them to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When you heard the voice from the center of the darkness while the mountain burned with fire, you came to me with all the heads of your families and your leaders.
speaker: Narrator

text: And you said, ‘See, the Lord our God has shown us His shining-greatness. We have heard His voice from the center of the fire. Today we have seen that God speaks with man and man still lives.
speaker: Narrator

text: But why should we die now? For this big fire will burn us up. If we hear the voice of the Lord our God any more, we will die.
speaker: Narrator

text: For who of all flesh has ever heard the voice of the living God speaking from the center of the fire, as we have heard, and lived?
speaker: Narrator

text: Go near and hear all the Lord our God says. Then tell us all the Lord our God says to you, and we will listen and do it.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Lord heard what you said when you spoke to me. And the Lord said to me, ‘I have heard the words which the people have spoken to you. They have done well in all that they have said.
speaker: Narrator

text: If only they had such a heart in them that they would fear Me and live by all My Laws always! Then it would go well with them and with their children forever.
speaker: Narrator

text: Go and say to them, “Return to your tents.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But you stand here by Me. And I will tell you all the Laws which you should teach them, so they may keep them in the land I give them for their own.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Be careful to do just as the Lord your God has told you. Do not turn aside to the right or to the left.
speaker: Narrator

text: Walk in all the way the Lord your God has told you. Then you may live, it may be well with you, and you may live a long time in the land that will belong to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “These are the Laws which the Lord your God has told me to teach you. You are to do them in the land you are going to take for your own.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you and your son and your grandson will fear the Lord your God. You will obey all His Laws that I tell you, all the days of your life. And then you will have a longer life.
speaker: Narrator

text: O Israel, you should listen and be careful to do them. Then it will go well with you. And you will become many in a land flowing with milk and honey. This is what the Lord, the God of your fathers, has promised you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Hear, O Israel! The Lord our God is one Lord!
speaker: Narrator

text: And you must love the Lord your God with all your heart and with all your soul and with all your strength.
speaker: Narrator

text: Keep these words in your heart that I am telling you today.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do your best to teach them to your children. Talk about them when you sit in your house and when you walk on the road and when you lie down and when you get up.
speaker: Narrator

text: Tie them as something special to see on your hand and on your forehead.
speaker: Narrator

text: Write them beside the door of your house and on your gates.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Lord your God will bring you into the land He promised to your fathers, Abraham, Isaac and Jacob, to give to you. There will be big and beautiful cities which you did not build.
speaker: Narrator

text: Houses will be full of good things which you did not fill. There will be pools for keeping water which you did not dig, and grape vines and olive trees which you did not plant. You will eat and be filled.
speaker: Narrator

text: But then be careful not to forget the Lord Who brought you from the land of Egypt, out of the land where you were held as servants.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must fear the Lord your God. You must worship Him, and swear by His name.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not follow other gods, any of the gods of the people around you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Or the anger of the Lord your God will burn against you. He will destroy you from the earth. For the Lord your God Who is among you is a jealous God.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Do not test the Lord your God, as you put Him to the test at Massah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be careful to keep all the Laws which the Lord your God has told you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do what is right and good in the eyes of the Lord. Then it will be well with you. And you may go in and take the good land for your own which the Lord promised to give to your fathers.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will drive out of your way all who hate you, as the Lord has promised.
speaker: Narrator

text: “In time to come your son will ask you, ‘What do all the Laws mean which the Lord told you?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then say to your son, ‘We were servants of Pharaoh in Egypt. But the Lord brought us out of Egypt with a strong hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord showed us great and powerful works against Egypt, Pharaoh, and all those of his house.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord brought us out from there to bring us into the land He had promised to our fathers.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord told us to do all these Laws and to fear the Lord our God for our good always, as it is today.
speaker: Narrator

text: We will be right with the Lord our God if we are careful to obey all of the Law before Him, just as He told us.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Lord your God will bring you into the land you are taking for your own. He will drive away many nations in front of you, the Hittites, the Girgashites, the Amorites, the Canaanites, the Perizzites, the Hivites, and the Jebusites, seven nations bigger and stronger than you.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Lord your God gives them to you and you win the battles against them, you must destroy all of them. Make no agreement with them and show no favor to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not take any of them in marriage. Do not give your daughters to their sons. And do not take their daughters for your sons.
speaker: Narrator

text: For they will turn your sons away from following Me to serve other gods. Then the anger of the Lord will burn against you. And He will be quick to destroy you.
speaker: Narrator

text: But do this to them: Break down their altars. Crush their objects of worship. Cut down their female goddess Asherim. And burn their false gods with fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: “For you are a holy nation to the Lord your God. The Lord your God has chosen you out of all the nations on the earth, to be His own.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord did not give you His love and choose you because you were more people than any of the nations. For the number of your people was less than all nations.
speaker: Narrator

text: But it is because the Lord loves you and is keeping the promise He made to your fathers. So the Lord brought you out by a strong hand. He set you free from the land where you were servants, and from the power of Pharaoh king of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Know then that the Lord your God is God, the faithful God. He keeps His promise and shows His loving-kindness to those who love Him and keep His Laws, even to a thousand family groups in the future.
speaker: Narrator

text: But He destroys those who hate Him. He will not show kindness to the one who hates Him, but will punish him to his face.
speaker: Narrator

text: So keep and obey all the Laws I am telling you today.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If you listen to these Laws and keep and obey them, the Lord your God will keep His agreement and loving-kindness as He promised to your fathers.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will love you and bring good to you and make you a nation of many. He will bring good to your children and the fruit of your land, your grain, your new wine and your oil. And He will give you many cattle and young ones in your flock, in the land He promised to your fathers to give you.
speaker: Narrator

text: More good will come to you than to any other nation. There will be no male or female among you or your cattle that is not able to have young ones.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will take all sickness from you. He will not let any bad diseases come upon you that you have known in Egypt. But He will give them to all who hate you.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will destroy all the nations the Lord your God will give to you. You will not pity them or worship their gods, for that would be a trap to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You may say in your heart, ‘These nations are stronger than I. How can I drive them out?’
speaker: Narrator

text: But you will not be afraid of them. You will remember what the Lord your God did to Pharaoh and to all Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will remember the hard trials you saw, the powerful works, and the strong hand and powerful arm the Lord your God used to bring you out. The Lord your God will do the same to all the nations who make you afraid.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord your God will send the hornet against them. Those who are left will hide themselves from you and be destroyed.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will not be afraid of them. For the Lord your God is among you, a great and powerful God.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord your God will drive away these nations in front of you one by one. You will not be able to destroy them in a short time, or the wild animals may become too many for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord your God will give them to you. He will bring much trouble upon them until they are destroyed.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will give their kings into your hand. And you will destroy their name from under heaven. No man will be able to stand in front of you until you have destroyed them.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must burn with fire their objects of worship. Do not want the silver or gold that is on them, or take it for yourselves. It would be a trap to you, for it is a hated thing to the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not bring a hated thing into your house. You would become hated also. But turn from it with fear and hate, for bad will come from it.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Be careful to do all that I am telling you today. Then you will live and have many children, and go in to own the land the Lord promised to give to your fathers.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will remember all the way the Lord your God led you in the desert these forty years, so you would not have pride, and how He tested you to know what was in your heart to see if you would obey His Laws or not.
speaker: Narrator

text: He let you be hungry which helped you to not have pride. Then He fed you with bread from heaven which you and your fathers had not known. He did this to make you understand that man does not live by bread alone. But man lives by everything that comes out of the mouth of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your clothes did not wear out, and your feet did not get sore during these forty years.
speaker: Narrator

text: So know in your heart that the Lord your God was punishing you just as a man punishes his son.
speaker: Narrator

text: Keep the Laws of the Lord your God. Walk in His ways, and fear Him.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Lord your God is bringing you into a good land, a land of rivers and wells of water, flowing into valleys from hills.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is a land of grains, vines, fig trees, fruit, olive oil and honey.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is a land where you will have enough food to eat and not have to do without, a land where stones are iron. And you can make brass from what you dig out of its hills.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you have eaten and are filled, you will honor and thank the Lord your God for the good land He has given you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Be careful not to forget the Lord your God by not keeping all His Laws which I am telling you today.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you have eaten and are filled, and have built good houses to live in,
speaker: Narrator

text: and when your cattle and flocks become many, and you get much silver and gold, and have many things for your own,
speaker: Narrator

text: be careful not to become proud. Do not forget the Lord your God Who brought you out of the land of Egypt, out of the house where you were servants.
speaker: Narrator

text: He led you through the big desert that brought fear with its poisonous snakes and scorpions and thirsty ground where there was no water. He brought you water out of hard rock.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the desert He fed you bread from heaven, which your fathers did not know about. He did this so you would not have pride and that He might test you. It was for your good in the end.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be careful not to say in your heart, ‘My power and strong hand have made me rich.’
speaker: Narrator

text: But remember the Lord your God. For it is He Who is giving you power to become rich. By this He may keep His agreement which He promised to your fathers, as it is this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you ever forget the Lord your God and go to other gods to worship and work for them, I tell you today that you will be destroyed for sure.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will be destroyed like the nations the Lord destroys before you, because you would not listen to the voice of the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Hear, O Israel! You are crossing over the Jordan today to take the land that belongs to nations greater and stronger than you, with big cities with walls as high as heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people there are strong and tall, the sons of Anakim. You know of them and have heard it said, ‘Who can stand in front of the sons of Anak?’
speaker: Narrator

text: But know today that it is the Lord your God Who is crossing over before you as a fire that destroys everything. He will destroy them and bring them down before you. So you may drive them out and be quick to destroy them, just as the Lord has told you.
speaker: Narrator

text: But after the Lord your God has driven them out before you, do not say in your heart, ‘The Lord has brought me in to take this land because I am right and good.’ It is because of the sin of these nations that the Lord is driving them out in front of you.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is not because of your being right with God that you are going to take their land. But it is because of the sin of these nations that the Lord your God is driving them out in front of you. By this the Lord is proving that He keeps the promise He made to your fathers, to Abraham, Isaac and Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text: Understand that it is not because you are right with God that the Lord your God is giving you this good land for your own, for you are a strong-willed people.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Remember and do not forget how you made the Lord your God angry in the desert. You have gone against the Lord from the day you left the land of Egypt until you came to this place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even at Mount Sinai you made the Lord angry. The Lord was so angry with you that He would have destroyed you.
speaker: Narrator

text: I went up the mountain to receive the pieces of stone, the Laws of the agreement which the Lord had made with you. I stayed on the mountain forty days and nights. I did not eat bread or drink water.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord gave me the two pieces of stone written by the finger of God. On them were all the words the Lord had spoken with you on the mountain from the fire on the day of the meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the end of forty days and nights the Lord gave me the two pieces of stone, the Laws of the agreement.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to me, ‘Get up. Hurry and go down from here. For your people whom you brought out of Egypt have become very sinful. They have been quick to turn away from what I told them. They have made a false god for themselves.’
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord said to me, ‘I have seen these people. See, they are strong-willed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let Me alone, so I may destroy them and destroy their name from under heaven. I will make you into a nation that will be greater and stronger than they.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So I turned and came down from the mountain while the mountain was burning with fire. The two pieces of stone of the agreement were in my two hands.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I saw that it was true that you had sinned against the Lord your God. You had made for yourselves a calf out of gold. You had been quick to turn away from what the Lord had told you.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I took the two pieces of stone and threw them from my hands, and broke them in front of your eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then again I fell down before the Lord for forty days and nights. I did not eat bread or drink water, because of all the sin you had done. You did what was sinful in the eyes of the Lord and made Him angry.
speaker: Narrator

text: I was afraid of the anger of the Lord which was burning against you to destroy you. But the Lord listened to me again.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord was angry enough with Aaron to destroy him. So I prayed for Aaron at the same time also.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I took your sinful thing, the calf you had made, and burned it with fire and crushed it. I ground it into pieces until it was as fine as dust. And I threw its dust into the river that flowed down from the mountain.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You made the Lord angry again at Taberah, Massah and Kibroth-hattaavah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord sent you from Kadesh-barnea, saying, ‘Go and take for your own the land I have given you.’ But you went against what the Lord your God told you to do. You did not believe Him or listen to His voice.
speaker: Narrator

text: You have gone against the Lord from the day I first knew you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “So I fell down before the Lord and lay forty days and nights, because the Lord had said He would destroy you.
speaker: Narrator

text: I prayed to the Lord, saying, ‘O Lord God, do not destroy Your people, Your chosen nation, whom You have set free by Your power and brought out of Egypt with a strong hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: Remember Your servants, Abraham, Isaac and Jacob. Do not look at the strong will or sin or wrong-doing of these people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Or the land You brought us from may say, “The Lord was not able to bring them into the land He promised them. Because He hated them, He brought them out to kill them in the desert.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet they are Your people, Your chosen nation, whom You have brought out by Your great power and Your long arm.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “At that time the Lord said to me, ‘Cut out for yourself two pieces of stone like the other ones. Then come up to Me on the mountain, and make a box of wood.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will write on the pieces of stone the words that were on the other pieces of stone which you broke. And you will put them in the box.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So I made a box of acacia wood and cut out two pieces of stone like the other ones. Then I went up the mountain with the two stone pieces in my hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord wrote the Ten Laws the same as before on the pieces of stone which He had spoken to you on the mountain from the fire on the day of the meeting. And the Lord gave them to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I turned and came down from the mountain, and put the stone pieces in the box I had made. There they are, as the Lord told me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: (The people of Israel traveled from the wells of the sons of Jaakan to Moserah. Aaron died there and was buried and his son Eleazar took his place as religious leader.
speaker: Narrator

text: From there they traveled to Gudgodah. And from Gudgodah they went to Jotbathah, a land of rivers of water.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time the Lord set apart the family of Levi to carry the special box of the Law of the Lord, and to stand before the Lord to work for Him and honor His name to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Levi does not have a share of what is given to his brothers. The Lord is his share, just as the Lord your God promised him.)
speaker: Narrator

text: “Once more I stayed on the mountain forty days and forty nights, like the first time. And the Lord listened to me that time also. The Lord did not destroy you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to me, ‘Get up. Travel in front of the people, so they may go in and take the land which I promised to give their fathers.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “And now, Israel, what does the Lord your God ask of you? He wants you to fear the Lord your God, to walk in all His ways and love Him. He wants you to serve the Lord your God with all your heart and all your soul.
speaker: Narrator

text: He wants you to keep all the Laws of the Lord which I am telling you today for your good.
speaker: Narrator

text: See, heaven and the highest heavens, the earth and all that is in it belong to the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord had joy in loving your fathers more than other nations, and you are still His chosen people to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: So then, from now on, obey the Lord. Do not be strong-willed any more.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Lord your God is the God of gods and the Lord of lords. He is the great and powerful God and is to be honored with fear. He does not show favor, and cannot be bought with money.
speaker: Narrator

text: He does what is right and fair for the child without parents and the woman whose husband has died. He shows His love for the stranger by giving him food and clothing.
speaker: Narrator

text: So show your love for the stranger. For you were strangers in the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Fear the Lord your God. Work for Him, hold on to Him, and swear by His name.
speaker: Narrator

text: He is your praise and He is your God. You have seen the great and powerful things He has done for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your fathers went to Egypt, seventy people in all. And now the Lord your God has made you as many as the stars of heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Love the Lord your God. Always do what He tells you and keep all His Laws.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am not speaking to your children. They have not seen how the Lord worked and how great He is.
speaker: Narrator

text: They have not seen the special things you have seen, what He did in Egypt to Pharaoh the king of Egypt and to all his land.
speaker: Narrator

text: They have not seen what He did to Egypt’s army, the horses and war-wagons. He made the water of the Red Sea flow over them while they were coming after you. He destroyed every one of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: They have not seen what He did to you in the desert until you came to this place.
speaker: Narrator

text: They do not know what He did to Dathan and Abiram, the sons of Eliab, son of Reuben. The earth opened its mouth and swallowed them, those of their house, their tents, and every living thing that followed them among Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: But your own eyes have seen all the great work the Lord has done.
speaker: Narrator

text: “So keep every Law which I am telling you today. And you will be strong and go in and take the land which is to be yours.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will live long in the land the Lord promised to your fathers and their children, a land flowing with milk and honey.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the land you are going in to take is not like the land you came from in Egypt. There you planted your seed and watered it using your feet, like a vegetable garden.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the land you are about to go into and take for your own is a land of hills and valleys. It drinks water from the rain of heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord your God cares for this land. His eyes watch over it from the beginning to the end of the year.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Listen to and obey all the Laws I am telling you today. Love the Lord your God. Work for Him with all your heart and soul. If you do,
speaker: Narrator

text: He will give the rain for your land at the right times, the early and late rain. So you may gather in your grain, your new wine and your oil.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will give grass in your fields for your cattle. And you will eat and be filled.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be careful not to let your hearts be fooled so you turn away and work for other gods and worship them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Or the anger of the Lord will burn against you. He will shut the heavens so there will be no rain and the ground will not give its fruit. Then you will be quick to die from the good land the Lord is giving you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Keep these words of mine in your heart and in your soul. Tie them as something special to see upon your hand and on your forehead between your eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Teach them to your children. Talk about them when you sit in your house and when you walk on the road and when you lie down and when you get up.
speaker: Narrator

text: Write them beside the door of your house and on your gates.
speaker: Narrator

text: And your days and the days of your children will become many in the land the Lord promised to give to your fathers, as long as the heavens are above the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be careful to obey all this Law which I am telling you. Love the Lord your God. Walk in all His ways and hold on to Him. If you do,
speaker: Narrator

text: the Lord will drive out all these nations in front of you. And you will take for your own what has belonged to nations greater and stronger than you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every place where your foot steps will be yours. Your land will be from the desert to Lebanon, and from the River Euphrates to the sea in the west.
speaker: Narrator

text: There no man will be able to stand in front of you. The Lord your God will put the fear of you on all the land where you walk, as He has promised you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “See, I am putting in front of you today good and a curse.
speaker: Narrator

text: Good will come to you if you listen to the Laws of the Lord your God, which I am telling you today.
speaker: Narrator

text: But a curse will come to you if you do not listen to the Laws of the Lord your God and turn aside from the way I am telling you today, by following other gods you have not known.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Lord your God brings you into the land which is to be yours, you are to speak on Mount Gerizim about the good and on Mount Ebal the curses.
speaker: Narrator

text: You know they are on the other side of the Jordan, west of the road where the sun goes down. They are in the land of the Canaanites who live in the Arabah, beside Gilgal, next to the trees of Moreh.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are about to cross the Jordan to go in to take the land the Lord your God is giving you. It will be your land and you will live in it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be careful to obey all the Laws which I am giving you today.
speaker: Narrator

text: “These are the Laws you should be careful to obey in the land which the Lord, the God of your fathers, has given you for your own as long as you live on the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be sure to destroy all the places of worship of the nations whose place you are taking. Destroy them on the high mountains, on the hills, and under every green tree.
speaker: Narrator

text: Break down their altars and crush their pillars of worship. Burn their wooden female gods of worship named Asherim with fire. Cut down the objects made to look like their gods. And destroy their name from that place.
speaker: Narrator

text: But do not act like this toward the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Look for the Lord at the place which the Lord your God will choose from all your family groups. There He will make His name known, and make His home there, and there you will come.
speaker: Narrator

text: Bring to this place your burnt gifts, your gifts of worship, the tenth part of what you receive, the gifts of your hands, your promises, your free-will gifts, and the first-born of your cattle and your flock.
speaker: Narrator

text: You and those of your house will eat there before the Lord your God, and have joy in all that you do, in which the Lord your God has brought good to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will not do at all the things we are doing here today, for every man is doing whatever is right in his own eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text: For you have not yet come to the resting place and the land the Lord your God is giving you.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will cross the Jordan and live in the land the Lord your God is giving you. He will give you rest from all those around you who hate you, so you will be safe.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then bring all I tell you to the place where the Lord your God will choose to make His name known. Bring your burnt gifts, your gifts of worship, the tenth part of what you receive, the gifts of your hands, and all the special gifts that you promised to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be full of joy before the Lord your God, you and your sons and daughters, your men and women servants, and the Levite within your town who has no share of their gift.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be careful that you do not give your burnt gifts in just any place you see.
speaker: Narrator

text: But give your burnt gifts in the place which the Lord chooses in the land where your families live. There you should do all that I tell you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But you may kill and eat meat within any of your towns, as much as you want, as the Lord your God has given you His good gifts. Both the clean and the unclean may eat of it, as you would of the gazelle and the deer.
speaker: Narrator

text: Only do not eat the blood. You are to pour it out on the ground like water.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are not allowed to eat within your towns the tenth part of your grain, or new wine, or oil, or the first-born of your cattle or flock, or any of your promised gifts, or your free-will gifts, or the gifts of your hands.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you should eat them before the Lord your God in the place which the Lord your God will choose, you and your son and daughter, your men and women servants, and the Levite who is within your towns. Be full of joy before the Lord your God in everything you do.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be careful that you do not stop caring for the Levites as long as you live in your land.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Lord your God will give you more land as He has promised you. And when you say, ‘I will eat meat,’ because you want to eat meat, then you may eat as much meat as you want.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the place where the Lord your God chooses to put His name is too far from you, then you may kill from your cattle or flock which the Lord has given you, as I have told you, and you may eat within your towns whatever you want.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will eat it just as a gazelle or a deer is eaten. Both the clean and unclean may eat of it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Only be sure not to eat the blood. For the blood is the life. You must not eat the life with the flesh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not eat it, but pour it out on the ground like water.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not eat it, so it may go well with you and your children after you. For you will be doing what is right in the eyes of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Take your holy things which you may have and all the special gifts you promised to give to the place which the Lord chooses.
speaker: Narrator

text: Give your burnt gifts, the flesh and the blood, on the altar of the Lord your God. The blood of your gifts will be poured out on the altar of the Lord your God. And you will eat the flesh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be careful to listen to all these words I am telling you. Then it will go well with you and your children after you forever. For you will be doing what is good and right in the eyes of the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Lord your God will cut off before you the nations whose land you will take. You will take their place and live in their land.
speaker: Narrator

text: But be careful that you are not fooled into following them, after they are destroyed before you. Do not ask about their gods, saying, ‘How do these nations worship their gods so that I may do the same?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not act this way toward the Lord your God. For they have done for their gods every sinful act which the Lord hates. They even burn their sons and daughters in the fire for their gods.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Be careful to do whatever I tell you. Do not add to it or take away from it.
speaker: Narrator

text: “A man who tells what is going to happen or a dreamer of dreams may come among you. He may give you something special to see or do a powerful work.
speaker: Narrator

text: And what he tells you will happen might come true. But if he says to you, ‘Let us follow other gods (whom you have not known) and let us worship them,’
speaker: Narrator

text: do not listen to the words of that man who tells you what will happen or that dreamer of dreams. For the Lord your God is putting you to the test to see if you love the Lord your God with all your heart and with all your soul.
speaker: Narrator

text: Follow the Lord your God and fear Him. Keep His Laws, and listen to His voice. Work for Him, and hold on to Him.
speaker: Narrator

text: But that man who tells what is going to happen or that dreamer of dreams must be put to death, because he has talked to you about turning away from the Lord your God Who brought you from the land of Egypt and set you free from the land where you were servants. That man tried to turn you from the way the Lord your God told you to walk. You must take the sinful away from you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Your brother, your mother’s son, or your son or daughter, or the wife you love, or your friend who is as your own soul, might tempt you in secret. They might say, ‘Let us go and worship other gods’ (whom you and your fathers have not known.
speaker: Narrator

text: They might be gods of the nations who are around you, near you, or far from you, from one end of the earth to the other).
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not agree with him or listen to him. Do not look on him with pity. And do not show him loving-kindness or hide him.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must kill him. Your hand should be first against him to put him to death, and then the hand of all the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Kill him with stones, because he has tried to turn you away from the Lord your God Who brought you out of the land of Egypt, out of the land where you were servants.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all Israel will hear and be afraid. No one will do such a sinful thing among you again.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You might hear that in one of the cities the Lord your God has given you to live in
speaker: Narrator

text: that some men of no worth have gone out from among you to tempt those who live in their city. They might say, ‘Let us go and worship other gods,’ (whom you have not known).
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you should ask around and try to find out if this is true. If it is true that this sinful thing has been done among you,
speaker: Narrator

text: you must be sure to go against those of that city with the sword. Destroy all of it, all that is in it, and its cattle, with the sword.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then gather all that is left into the center of the city. Burn the city and all that is left in it with fire as a whole burnt gift to the Lord your God. It will be destroyed forever. It will never be built again.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let nothing of the things to be destroyed be kept in your own hand so the Lord may turn from His burning anger and show loving-kindness to you. He will show you loving-pity and make you a nation of many, just as He promised your fathers.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you must listen to the voice of the Lord your God. Obey all His Laws which I am telling you today. Do what is right in the eyes of the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You are the sons of the Lord your God. Do not cut yourselves or cut the hair from your foreheads because of the dead.
speaker: Narrator

text: For you are a holy nation to the Lord your God. The Lord has chosen you to be His own nation out of all the nations on the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Do not eat any hated thing.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the animals you may eat: the bull, the sheep, the goat,
speaker: Narrator

text: the deer, the gazelle, the roebuck, the wild goat, the ibex, the antelope, and the mountain sheep.
speaker: Narrator

text: And you may eat any animal that has a parted foot divided in two and that chews its food again.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you must not eat of those that chew their food again or have a divided foot: the camel, the rabbit and the rock badger. For though they eat their food again, they do not have a divided foot. They are unclean to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: And do not eat the pig, because it has a divided foot but does not chew its food again. It is unclean for you. Do not eat any of their flesh or touch their dead bodies.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Of all that are in the water, you may eat anything that has fins and scales.
speaker: Narrator

text: But do not eat anything that does not have fins and scales. It is unclean for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You may eat any clean bird.
speaker: Narrator

text: But these are the ones you may not eat: the eagle, the vulture, the buzzard,
speaker: Narrator

text: the red kite, the falcon, every kind of kite,
speaker: Narrator

text: every kind of raven,
speaker: Narrator

text: the ostrich, the owl, the sea gull, every kind of hawk,
speaker: Narrator

text: the little owl, the great owl, the white owl,
speaker: Narrator

text: the pelican, the vulture that eats dead flesh, the cormorant,
speaker: Narrator

text: the stork, every kind of heron, the hoopoe and the bat.
speaker: Narrator

text: And all flying bugs are unclean for you. Do not eat them.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you may eat any clean bird.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Do not eat anything that dies of itself. You may give it to the stranger in your town, so he may eat it. Or you may sell it to a person from another land. For you are a holy nation to the Lord your God.
“Do not boil a young goat in its mother’s milk.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Be sure to give a tenth part to the Lord of all you plant that comes from your field every year.
speaker: Narrator

text: Before the Lord your God, at the place He chooses to put His name, you may eat the tenth part of your grain, your new wine, your oil, and the first-born of your cattle and your flock. Then you may learn to fear the Lord your God always.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the place where the Lord your God chooses to put His name is too far away for you to bring the tenth part of all the good things you have received,
speaker: Narrator

text: you should trade it for money. Then tie the money in your hand and go to the place which the Lord your God chooses.
speaker: Narrator

text: You may spend the money for whatever your heart may desire, for bulls, sheep, wine, strong drink, or whatever you desire. And there you and those of your house may eat before the Lord and be full of joy.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not stop caring for the Levite who is in your town for he has no share of what is given to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “At the end of every third year you should bring the tenth part of that year’s grain into your towns.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Levite who has no share of what is given to you, and the stranger, and the child without parents, and the woman whose husband has died, who are in your towns, may come and eat and be filled. Then the Lord your God will bring good to you in all the work done by your hands.
speaker: Narrator

text: “At the end of every seven years you must do away with debts that are owed.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the way you are to do it: Every man who has loaned money must forget the debt. He cannot make his neighbor and his brother pay it because the Lord has said that all should be forgotten.
speaker: Narrator

text: You may make a stranger pay what he owes, but not your brother.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet there will be no poor among you for the Lord will be sure to bring good to you in the land the Lord your God is giving you for your own.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you must listen and obey the voice of the Lord your God. Be careful to do all the Law which I am telling you today.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord your God will bring good to you as He has promised. You will let many nations use what belongs to you but you will not use what belongs to them. You will rule over many nations but they will not rule over you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “In any of the towns in your land the Lord your God is giving you, if there is anyone poor among you, do not let your heart be hard and not be willing to help him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be free to give to him. Let him use what is yours of anything he needs.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be careful that there is no sinful thought in your heart, saying, ‘It is almost the seventh year, the time to do away with the debt owed to me,’ so you look on your brother with hate and give him nothing. Then he may cry to the Lord against you and you may be guilty of sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: Give much to him, without being sorry that you do. Because the Lord your God will bring good to you for this, in all your work and in everything you do.
speaker: Narrator

text: The poor will always be in the land. So I tell you to be free in giving to your brother, to those in need, and to the poor in your land.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If your brother, a Hebrew man or a Hebrew woman, is sold to you, he will work for you six years. But you must set him free in the seventh year.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you set him free, do not send him away with nothing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Give him much from your flock, from your grain, and from your wine. Give to him as the Lord your God has given to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Remember that you were servants in the land of Egypt, and the Lord your God set you free. And so I am telling you today to do this.
speaker: Narrator

text: But he may say to you, ‘I will not leave you,’ because he loves you and those of your house and gets along well with you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then take a sharp tool and put it through his ear into the door. And he will be your servant forever. Do the same with your woman servant.
speaker: Narrator

text: It should not be hard for you to set him free for he has worked for you six years. He has been worth twice as much as a man paid to work for you. The Lord your God will bring good to you in whatever you do.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Set apart for the Lord your God all the first-born males among your cattle and your flock. Do no work with the first-born of your cattle. Do not cut the wool from the first-born of your flock.
speaker: Narrator

text: You and those of your house will eat it every year before the Lord your God in the place the Lord chooses.
speaker: Narrator

text: But do not kill it and give it to the Lord your God if it is not perfect, such as not being able to walk or see, or anything else wrong with it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eat it within your towns. Both the clean and the unclean may eat it, as if it were a gazelle or deer.
speaker: Narrator

text: But do not eat its blood. You must pour it out on the ground like water.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Remember the month of Abib and keep the Passover to the Lord your God. For the Lord your God brought you out of Egypt during the night in the month of Abib.
speaker: Narrator

text: Give the Passover gift to the Lord your God from the flock and the cattle, in the place where the Lord chooses to put His name.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not eat bread made with yeast. For seven days eat bread made without yeast, the bread of sorrow, because you came out of the land of Egypt in a hurry. So all the days of your life you will remember the day when you came out of the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: For seven days there is to be no yeast around in all your land. And none of the flesh you give in worship on the evening of the first day will be kept through the night until morning.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are not allowed to give the Passover gift in any of your towns the Lord your God gives you.
speaker: Narrator

text: But give it at the place where the Lord your God chooses to put His name. You must kill the Passover gift in the evening when the sun goes down, at the time that you came out of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Make it ready and eat it in the place the Lord your God chooses. Then return to your tents in the morning.
speaker: Narrator

text: For six days eat bread made without yeast. On the seventh day there will be a holy meeting to the Lord your God. Do no work on this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Number seven weeks. Begin to number seven weeks from the time you begin to cut the standing grain.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then keep the Special Supper of Weeks to the Lord your God by giving a free-will gift. Give as the Lord your God has given to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be full of joy before the Lord your God, you and your son and daughter, your men and women servants, the Levite who is in your town, the stranger, the child whose parents have died, and the woman whose husband has died. Be full of joy in the place where the Lord your God chooses to put His name.
speaker: Narrator

text: Remember that you were servants in Egypt. And be careful to obey these Laws.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Keep the Special Supper of Tents seven days after you have gathered your grain and wine.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be full of joy during your special supper, you and your son and daughter, your men and women servants, the Levite, the stranger, the child whose parents have died, and the woman whose husband has died, who are in your towns.
speaker: Narrator

text: Seven days you will have a special supper to the Lord your God in the place which the Lord chooses. You will be full of joy because the Lord your God will bring good to you in all the food you grow and in all the work you do.
speaker: Narrator

text: All your males must show themselves before the Lord your God three times a year in the place He chooses, at the Special Supper of Bread Without Yeast, the Special Supper of the First Fruits of the Land, and the Special Supper of Tents. They must not show themselves before the Lord with nothing in their hands.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every man should give as he is able, as the Lord your God has given to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Choose judges and other leaders for all your towns the Lord your God is giving you, among each of your family groups. They must be wise in judging the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be fair and do not show favor. Do not take pay in secret for doing wrong. Such pay blinds the eyes of the wise and causes them to change the words of a good man.
speaker: Narrator

text: Follow what is right, and only what is right. Then you will live and receive the land the Lord your God is giving you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When you make an altar for the Lord your God, do not put beside it a wooden god like the false goddess Asherah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not set up for yourself a pillar for worship that the Lord your God hates.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Do not give to the Lord your God a bull or a sheep which is not perfect. For that is a hated thing to the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You may find among you, within any of your towns the Lord your God gives you, a man or a woman who does what is sinful in the eyes of the Lord your God by sinning against the Lord’s agreement.
speaker: Narrator

text: If he has served other gods and worshiped them, or the sun, or the moon or the stars, which I have told him not to worship,
speaker: Narrator

text: and if someone told you about this, then you should do your best to find out if it is true. If it is true that this hated thing has been done in Israel,
speaker: Narrator

text: then bring that man or woman who has done this sinful act to your gates, and kill the man or woman with stones.
speaker: Narrator

text: If two or three people tell what they know against this person, he who is to die must be put to death. But he should not be put to death if only one person speaks against him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who speak against him should be first to put him to death. And then all the people should join them. You must get rid of all sin from among you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “There may be a problem too hard for you to decide, between two kinds of killing, between two kinds of questions about the law, between two kinds of hurting, problems argued about in your courts. Then get up and go to the place which the Lord your God chooses.
speaker: Narrator

text: Go to the Levite religious leader or the judge who is at work at that time. Ask them, and they will tell you what they decide.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then do what should be done by what they tell you they have decided at that place which the Lord chooses. Be careful to do all they tell you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do what they teach you about the Law and about what they decide. Do not turn aside from what they tell you to do, to the right or to the left.
speaker: Narrator

text: The man must die who does foolish things and will not listen to the judge or the religious leader who serves the Lord your God. You must get rid of sin from Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all the people will hear and be afraid. They will not act in a foolish way again.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When you go into the land the Lord your God gives you, and own it and live in it, and you say, ‘I will have a king rule over me like all the nations around me,’
speaker: Narrator

text: then you will set a king over you whom the Lord your God chooses. Set a king over you from among your brothers. Do not give a stranger power over you if he is not your brother.
speaker: Narrator

text: He must not take many horses for himself or make the people return to Egypt to get many horses. Because the Lord has told you, ‘You must never again return that way.’
speaker: Narrator

text: He must not take many wives for himself or his heart may turn away. And he must not gather much silver and gold for himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When he sits on the throne of his nation, he should write this Law for himself in a book in front of the Levite religious leaders.
speaker: Narrator

text: It should be kept with him and he should read it all the days of his life. Then he will learn to fear the Lord his God, by being careful to obey all the words of these Laws.
speaker: Narrator
